abstractContent.text: We propose a novel recurrent neural network-based approach to simultaneously handle nested named entity recognition and nested entity mention detection.
The model learns a hypergraph representation for nested entities using features extracted from a recurrent neural network.
In evaluations on three standard data sets, we show that our approach significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods , which are feature-based.
The approach is also efficient: it operates linearly in the number of tokens and the number of possible output labels at any token.
Finally, we present an extension of our model that jointly learns the head of each entity mention.

introductionContent.text: Named entity recognition (or named entity detection) is the task of identifying text spans associated with proper names and classifying them according to their semantic class such as person, organization, etc.

entities.text: Named entity recognition (or named entity detection) is the task of identifying text spans associated with proper names and classifying them according to their semantic class such as person, organization, etc.

introductionContent.text: It is related to the task of mention detection (or entity mention recognition) in which text spans referring to named, nominal or prominal entities are identified and classified according to their semantic class ().

Both named entity recognition and entity mention detection are fundamental components in information extraction systems: several downstream tasks such as relation extraction (), coreference resolution () and fine-grained opinion mining () rely on both.

Many approaches have been successfully employed for the tasks of named entity recognition and mention detection, including linear-chain conditional random fields () and semi-Markov conditional random fields).
However, most such methods suffer from an inability to handle nested named entities, nested entity mentions, or both.
As a result, the downstream tasks necessarily ignore these nested entities along with any semantic relations among them.

datasetContent.text: The ACE datasets also have annotations for mention heads along with the entity mentions.
For example, a sentence with the entity mention "the U.S. embassy" also contains an annotation for its headword which is "embassy" in this case.
Thus, we modify our model to also extract the head of the entity mentions for ACE dataset.
We jointly model the entity mentions and their heads.
To do this, we propose a simple extension to our model by only changing the output label sequence.
We introduce new labels starting with "H" to indicate that the current token in the entity mention is part of its head.
Thus, we only change the output label sequence for the entity mentions to include the head label: We train with the label sequence "B ORG I ORG H ORG" instead of "B ORG I ORG L ORG".

entities.text: B ORG I ORG H ORG

datasetContent.text: Also, for all our entity sequences we predict the "O" tag at the end, hence we can still extract the entity mentions.
At decoding time, we output the sequence of words with the "H" tag as the head words fora mention.
We evaluate our model on two tasks -nested entity mention detection for the ACE corpora and nested named entity recognition for the GENIA dataset.
We use a strict evaluation metric similar to: an entity mention is considered correct if both the mention span and the mention type are exactly correct.
Similarly, for the task of joint extraction of entity mentions and mention heads, the mention span, head span and the entity type should all exactly match the gold label.
